com.analog.lyric.dimple.model.domains

Class JointDiscreteDomain<Element>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.analog.lyric.dimple.model.domains.Domain
      • com.analog.lyric.dimple.model.domains.DiscreteDomain
        • com.analog.lyric.dimple.model.domains.TypedDiscreteDomain<Element[]>
          • com.analog.lyric.dimple.model.domains.JointDiscreteDomain<Element>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Iterable<Element[]>

    @Immutable
public class JointDiscreteDomain<Element>
extends TypedDiscreteDomain<Element[]>
    A discrete domain representing the Cartesian product of other discrete domains. Its elements are Java Object[] arrays with the nth element holding an element of the nth component domain.

    It is represented efficiently using a JointDomainIndexer, so the full combinatoric list of elements does not need to be produced unless someone calls DiscreteDomain.getElements().

    Construct instances using DiscreteDomain.joint(DiscreteDomain...) or DiscreteDomain.joint(JointDomainIndexer).

    See Also:
    Serialized Form

      • getElement

        public <T> T[] getElement(int i,
                 @Nullable
                 T[] array)
        Writes the subelements of the ith element in the domain into array and returns it.

        Parameters:
        i - must be in the range [0, size()-1].
        array - will only be used if non-null and no shorter than size(), otherwise a new array will be allocated.
        Returns:
        array containing ith element, which will be the same as array provided it was big enough.
        See Also:
        getElement(int), getElementIndices(int, int[])

      • getElementIndices

        public int[] getElementIndices(int i)
        Returns any array containing the individual subdomain indexes for the ith element in this domain.

        This is equivalent to calling getElementIndices(int, int[]) with a null second argument.

        Parameters:
        i - must be in the range [0, size()-1].
        Returns:
        newly allocated array of indices

      • getElementIndices

        public int[] getElementIndices(int i,
                      int[] array)
        Writes the individual subdomain indexes for the ith element in this domain into provided array and returns it.

        This is equivalent to calling getDomainIndexer().jointIndexToIndices(i, array)

        Parameters:
        i - must be in the range [0, size()-1].
        array - must be at least size() long or else a new array will be allocated.
        Returns:
        array containing indices, which will be same as provided array if it is large enough
        See Also:
        getElementIndices(int), getElement(int, Object[])
